profileText: (Father of Jonathan Dayton), a Delegate from New Jersey; born in Elizabethtown (now Elizabeth), N.J., May 1, 1737; apprenticed as a mechanic; completed preparatory studies; lieutenant of militia March 19, 1756, and captain March 19, 1760; served in the ``Jersey Blues'' under Wolfe at Quebec and against Pontiac near Detroit; proprietor of a general store at Elizabethtown, N.J.; alderman; member of committee to enforce measures recommended by Continental Congress, and on October 26, 1775, became one of Essex County's four muster-masters; commissioned a colonel of the third battalion of the New Jersey Line on January 10, 1776; elected to the Continental Congress December 12, 1778, in place of John Neilson, but declined May 25, 1779; was in active service until the discharge of the New Jersey Line on November 3, 1783; promoted to brigadier general January 8, 1783; returned to Elizabethtown and operated a general store; major general of militia; recorder of Elizabethtown in 1789; member of State general assembly 1791-1792 and 1794-1796; mayor of Elizabethtown 1796-1805; president of the New Jersey Society of the Cincinnati; died in Elizabethtown (now Elizabeth), N.J., October 22, 1807; interment in a vault in the First Presbyterian Churchyard.

researchRecord.name: In the William Livingston Papers, 1787, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from William Livingston to an unidentified recipient written on August 31, 1787 appointing Elias Dayton to be executor of the estate of his father, Jonathan Dayton.

researchRecord.name: In the Society of the Cincinnati Manuscripts Collection, ca. 1760-1900, 6 linear feet.
researchRecord.description: Persons represented include Elias Dayton. A finding aid is available in the repository.

researchRecord.name: 1759-1783, 34 items.
researchRecord.description: Correspondents include Philip Schuyler, Baron Friedrich Wilhelm von Steuben, and George Washington. Topics of the correspondence include military commissions, returns of New Jersey regiments, accounts of the battles of Brandywine and Germantown (1764) and the siege at Yorktown. A journal is included on the expedition (1764) against the Indians near Detroit (Pontiac's Conspiracy).

researchRecord.name: In the Military Orderly Books Collection, 1780, 1 volume.
researchRecord.description: An orderly book from the 3rd New Jersey Regiment of 1777. The regiment was commanded by Colonel Elias Dayton from 1776 until January 1, 1781.

researchRecord.name: In the William Alexander Papers, ca. 1767-1782, 1 linear foot.
1792, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Jonathan Dayton to his father, General Elias Dayton, written on March 15, 1792. Jonathan Dayton writes concerning his journey, and a certificate in favor of Luther Baldwin.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts

researchRecord.name: In Great Britain's Army Orderly Book, 1759, 1 volume.
researchRecord.description: This volume includes general orders issued to British and American troops under Jeffrey Amherst preparing for the attack on Ticonderoga. This book was written by Elias Dayton, who served as a lieutenant in the New Jersey militia on this campaign.

researchRecord.name: In the George Washington Papers, 1783, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from George Washington to Elias Dayton written on December 28, 1783. George Washington, as President of the Society of the Cincinnati, informs Elias Dayton, President of the New Jersey chapter, of plans for a general meeting to be held in Philadelphia in May.

researchRecord.name: In the Henry Knox Papers, 1782, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Henry Knox to Elias Dayton written on March 21, 1782 which directs Elias Dayton to provide an escort for the British commissioners appointed to meet with the Americans for an exchange of prisoners.

researchRecord.name: 1800, 0.2 linear foot.
researchRecord.description: Receipts and invoices for disbursements of provisions by Elias Dayton, general store owner and contractor, signed by Commander [Tim?] Taylor of the 13th Regiment at Elizabeth Town Point (now Elizabeth), New Jersey, in April, May, and June of 1800.

researchRecord.name: In the Jonathan Dayton Papers, 1792, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Jonathan Dayton to General Elias Dayton written on November 11, 1792. Jonathan Dayton writes concerning the federal and state elections of 1792 and the latest news from France.

researchRecord.name: 1782, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Elias Dayton to General Hand written on January 2, 1782, complying with orders he has received.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts

researchRecord.name: In the Edwin A. Ely Autograph Collection, ca. 1663-1890, 250 items.
In the Society of St. Tammany Invitation, 1788, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: An invitation from the Society of St. Tammany to General and Mrs. Elias Dayton written on April 26, 1788. The invitation is to the Society's St. Tammany Day celebration in Elizabeth on May 1.

researchRecord.name: In the William Hull Papers, 1792, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A circular letter signed by William Hull and written on April 14, 1792 to officers of the Continental Army. Other authors include Elias Dayton.

researchRecord.name: In the Petition by Citizens of New Jersey, 1775, 3 pages.
researchRecord.description: This petition by citizens of New Jersey to the Governor, Council, and Assembly for re-opening a road in Bergen County was written on January 16, 1775. Signers of the petition include Elias Dayton.
